utterances: And our kids would say, you know, stop fighting.
And we weren't fighting, we were just exploring it.
You were animated (laughter).
Yeah, we were just exploring a subject.
We care a lot.
But that's really one of the best parts of a collaboration, is that you can explore something.
And, you know, we have a rule that whoever's the most passionate wins.
And it's - you know, I still to this day, after decades of working with Val, you know, am surprised by what she has to say, and...
It is a little like a tennis match.
So, you know, it's just the constant...
...Back and forth.
Yeah, batting the ball back and forth - but it's what we like to do.
(SOUNDBITE OF AEROSMITH SONG, ""DREAM ON"")
Those were directors Valerie Faris and Jonathan Dayton.
Their new film is called ""Battle Of The Sexes.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
The whereabouts of Osama Bin Laden may be a seven-year-old question, but it still echoes through the halls of the Pentagon, and it still drives U.S.
foreign policy, at least in part.
Al-Qaeda lost its bases in Afghanistan, when U.S.-led forces toppled the Taliban, and many senior commanders have been captured or killed.
But both the Taliban andal -Qaeda have new bases just across the border in Pakistan.
According to reports, U.S.
Special Forces crossed that border yesterday to raid several houses in a Pakistani village.
While the U.S.
has made no official comment, the use of U.S.
ground troops and reports of civilian deaths caused uproar in politically precarious Pakistan just a couple of days before its presidential election.
With the seventh anniversary of September 11th a week away, are we any closer to finding Osama Bin Laden, containing al-Qaeda and stabilizing Afghanistan?
Later in the program, we continue our series of conversations on This American Moment.
This week from the Republican National Convention, we'll talk with John Fund of the Wall Street Journal about what's online in this election.
If you'd like to weigh in by email now, the address is talk@npr.org.
But first, seven years on, are Osama Bin Laden and al-Qaeda still your number one priority?
Our phone number is 800-989-8255, email us, talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
We begin with Pakistani journalist and author Ahmed Rashid.
His most recent book is ""Descent Into Chaos."" And he joins us now on the phone from Lahore in Pakistan.
And it's good to speak with you again.
Thank you.
And let's start with this raid into Pakistan yesterday.
What's been the response there in Islamabad, in Lahore?
Well, it's been very fierce, both by the civilian government and by the army, and the foreign minister has spoken out very strongly in parliament.
They've called the U.S.
ambassador in for a dressing down.
The army has given a very strong statement saying there's the possibility of retaliation, although what that exactly means we don't know.

And the army's insisting that there was nopre -warning by the United States, that there was no intelligence sharing that usually has happened in the past, and it was all over so quickly that in fact, the army did scramble its troops to try and resist this, but they didn't reach the place in time and the American soldiers were able get away in their helicopter.
What...
More than that, tonight, there are unconfirmed reports that there's been another missile strike from the Afghan side, presumably by U.S.
forces against anotheral-Qaeda house or some kind of target in the tribal areas.
That happened tonight.
And what effect might it have on the election just a couple of days away?
Well, it's obviously, you know, drawing a lot of attention away from the election.

A lot of people are speculating that - as you know, there was a very big military offensive in Bajaur, one of the tribal agencies along the border with Afghanistan, which went on for about three weeks.
And then, very suddenly, the army announced a cease-fire, saying that the militants had all been wiped out, and there was now a cease-fire for Ramadan.

Now, what people are suspecting is that this cease-fire is something that, first of all, probably angered the Americans and NATO forces in Afghanistan very much because just - about 10 days ago, Pakistan's army chief met with the chairman of the joint chiefs, Admiral Mullen, on a battleship in the Gulf where he got a lot of praise from the Americans.
So this cease-fire, I think, has come as a bit of a shock to the Americans.

But the other part of it is the speculation that the cease-fire might just be for the duration of the presidential elections and - because there was a problem of getting members of parliament to come to parliament from the tribal areas because the Taliban had been threatening to kill them.
So, the cease-fire was put in place so that these elections go off peacefully, and then the army would resume its offensive.

Now, that still has to be seen, but I think one reason for this very severe reaction by this Pakistani government has been possibly that the Pakistanis may have told the Americans that look, the cease-fire is only in place for a few days, just for these elections, don't get worked up, we'll resume the offensive after the elections.
But I think that could be a reason why the Pakistan army and government have reacted so aggressively against the American action.
But she still got the gig.
Signal Hill is a postage stamp of a city, two and a half square miles bordered by Long Beach.
Born out of the oil boom in the 1920s, it once had so many oil derricks it was called `Porcupine Hill.
Homes have now replaced most of them, as they have across the LA basin.
But oil is still being pumped.
Giant horse-head and grasshopper pumping units rock incessantly in restaurant parking lots, neighborhoods and on golf courses.
Eighty-one-year old Bob Lee owns four oil wells in Signal Hill, a stone's throw from million-dollar hilltop homes.
Originally, the property has had 20 wells drilled on it.
They were drilled in 1928 or thereabouts.
This is one of the most prolific 10 acres in the world.
It has recovered over 13 1/2 million barrels of oil.
That's only one-third of what's here.
Lee's wells, once owned by ARCO, originally produced 4,000 to 5,000 barrels a day, the easy oil, as it's known in the business.
Today, he's lucky to pump 25 to 30 barrels a day out of the one that's producing.
But that's not bad for a 77-year-old well and it's especially sweet at today's prices for California crude oil.
I'll say $50 a barrel.
It's making a little money right now and I'm very happy with that.
During the lean years in the late '90s when California oil was cheap, around $12 a barrel, and electricity prices were skyrocketing, independent producers shut down their less-productive wells.
There are about 3,000 idle wells in the LA basin, 20,000 statewide.
But now many owners are investing to get them pumping again.
Again, Bob Lee.
We have one well here that's 7,200 feet deep.
The engineers tell us we have an excellent chance of getting a 50-barrel well.
All of the idle wells can be put back on production after we do a little study to find out what needs to be done.
That's Professor Iraj Ershaghi, the head of the petroleum engineering program at the University of Southern California.
California's oil fields have yielded about 27 billion barrels of oil.
Typically, producers have walked away after extracting only 20 to 30 percent of the oil underground.
Right now there are technologies out there that you can produce 50 to 60 percent of what's in the ground.
Now 26 billion barrels added to the California reserve, that's a lot of oil.
California consumes 1.8 million barrels of oil a day, but it produces only 700,000 barrels a day.
All the rest, over a million barrels a day, is imported.
We're trying to suck a little harder to get a little more out.
Hal Washburn is CEO of BreitBurn Oil, an independent with 513 active and 200 idle wells in LA and Santa Barbara counties.
Every barrel we produce is one less barrel that has to come along the coastline in a tanker, and that's the way we look at our role.
Companies like BreitBurn use new horizontal and extended-reach drilling that allow them to reach oil up to five miles away from their rigs in inaccessible or even highly developed areas.
The state of California is waiving fees to encourage oil producers to get their idle wells pumping.
That's good for small producers like Bob Lee, but it's really the current price of oil that makes the risk of the investment easier to bear.
I think you have to be a half-gambler and a half-entrepreneur and you have to be able to deal with losses.
You could go down there and lose your money and it's all down at the bottom of that hole and you ain't going to get it back.
So there's always that chance that you might lose it.
Lee says he'll take the gamble.
He'll probably have to drop about half a million dollars into that idle 7,200-foot well to get the oil flowing again.
If all goes well and the price of crude holds steady, that well could be in the black in less than two years.
For NPR News, I'm Debra Behr.
Stay with us on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
From NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, in the most violent place in the world today, a calm voice of reason.
First, the lead, which is from that place: Iraq.
This has been the deadliest day there in months.
Five US soldiers died in a roadside bombing in Baghdad, but Iraqi civilians suffered far more casualties.
A suicide bomber in Karbala killed about 50 people and wounded scores more.
(Soundbite of site mayhem)
That was the scene in Karbala.
And in the city of Ramadi, another suicide bomber attacked a gathering of hundreds of police recruits.
Reports say about 50 people died there, too.
With us now from Baghdad is Borzou Daragahi; he's a reporter with the Los Angeles Times.
Borzou, a very, very bloody day.
Can you say why it is that these things all occurred today?
Well, no one's quite sure because we don't really understand the command and control structure of the insurgency.
But it definitely appears that the targets were not randomly chosen.

On the one hand, you had an attack on a Shiite mosque that is among the most revered sites in all of Shiite Islam--obviously, an attempt to draw Iraq's Shiite majority, generally turning the other cheek whenever they're attacked by the insurgents into an all-out civil war.

And in another instance, you had an attack on a recruiting center--from what we understand, a highly successful recruiting center, where they were recruiting Sunni Arabs into the Iraqi security forces--basically sending a message to Sunni Arabs, `If you throw your lot in with the current government, this is your fate.'
Borzou, the votes are still being tallied from Iraq's parliamentary elections last month.
What about the reports I see in The Associated Press that the various religious and ethnic factions may actually be close to achieving some kind of deal?
